transcript.content: Sammie Robinson Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I came to the penitentiary in 1953.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah. My prison number is 43209. I've already had two or three numbers since I've been here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so how old were you?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: How old me is now?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old were you when you came to Angola?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Just making 17. They kept me in the Parish 'til I made 17. I fell from there in Louisiana.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you tell me a little bit about the folks who raised you, your parents, when you were coming up? Tell me about your family.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Raised? There were no "raised," my daddy he stayed in trouble, my mama, she tried to raise us by herself.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you have any brothers and sisters?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How many?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I believe I had 4 sisters, and 5 brothers. I had a brother get killed down here 8 years ago at Camp H.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh okay. He was killed by another inmate?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, he was killed by another inmate.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: 8 years ago?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Might've been longer than that. At Camp H. He got killed there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about your mum. What kind of woman was she?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: She was a nice lady, she tried to raise us, help us, tell us things, but, we wind up being bad.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Aside from your brother who you said was at Camp H, did your other brothers end up getting in trouble?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, they raise trouble, I mean I got some in trouble now. They be in Texas, in the Texas penitentiary. I got two there. Really, I lost all of my family since I been in here so now I worry about myself.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. What was Angola like when you came here first?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Oh, it was rough, it was rough. Sometime I think about how I made it the way the penitentiary was. Right now, when I come here when I'm 17, I'm 80 years old now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. You survived.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah I survived. Sure did. I want to know how I survived. I had a tough time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: It's a very different prison today than it was when you came, for sure.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Of course it is. Penitentiary ain't nothing now. It's just like being in a boy's home. Big change.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember your first week here?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Do I remember my first week? Not really. I know when I come here they was doing a lot of working, I know that. They was cutting cane, picking cotton and things.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: When I come here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: They put you to work.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah. Working. In a line, and you had them inmate guards over us. There were guarding in case somebody run away.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did anybody escape while you were here?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Oh, a bunch of them escaped. Some of them got away, and some of them didn't.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. Did you ever try to escape?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, not really. I had a chance, but I didn't know I was going to be in this penitentiary that long.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I've been here 60 something years, and I'm a class A trusty..

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's right, you're a trusted member of the community. Mr. Robinson, do you want to get out of prison?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Do I want to get out of prison? That's quite a question, do I want to get out, no, I want to get out, I've spent half of my life in the penitentiary. Sure I'd like to get out. All I think about is trying to live, I might get out one day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If you were to get out, is there somebody who could take care of you?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Really, I'm going to put it to you like this: I don't really know, but if I get out, I got to place to go, like the halfway house, they going to help me find a place to live. I been getting letters from people in Baton Rouge at the halfway house writing me and things. See, like I said, I been here all my life. I ain't never really had a chance to get out. 'Because I been here all my life. I'd like to get out, Really, I have no business being here, 'cause by the time I got in Penitentiary here, I shouldn't have gotten it. That's the time I got right now. A 50 to life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Well, when you were sentenced to life, in those days, it meant 10-6.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What happened to the 10-6? Did you come before a parole board?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, I ain't never been parole. I been on the pardon board. But, the Governor, Edwards when you had that 10-6 life, he cut that out. Because he didn't want that dude to get out of the penitentiary. That dude that killed that lady in Lake Charles in that armed robbery, and cut that woman's throat. He didn't want that dude to get out, but he still got out!

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wilbert Rideau?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right! He got out, so Edwards had cut that out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: But somehow, the dude got out anyway.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you know Wilbert?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Did I know him? Yeah, he used to write on these Angolites and things yeah, I know him. Sure did.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. He's written a book about it. He's written a book about Angola.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right. He used to write. He used to write the Angolites over here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, he did. When he got out, he wrote a book about his life. I read it. It's good.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah. I ain't really heard nothing from him since he got out but he got out,

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where did you grow up?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Where I grow up? In Shreveport.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In Shreveport… was there a lot of fighting in your home when you grew up?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Did I have any fights?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: As a kid?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I had a few, when I was going to school, after I come to school, not really. There were no fighting at home.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When you came here I guess you kind of had to fight. When you came to Angola you had to fight.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Sure did. A little bit. Things was tough then. When I come here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. When did it start to change?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Well, after I was here a while and realize things, and seeing things, the older you get the more you learn. So I learnt a few things, but it was tough, serious, and I go along.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Mr. Robinson, do you mind if I ask you why, what lead to, your arms look like they were burnt.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I got burnt. I got burnt, here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How did that happen? Tell me about that.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Oh, 3rd degree burns, you see, they used to sell cigarette lighters, lighter fluid and all that. I had a dude throw some on me, in the cell, I was in the cell, locked down. In a block right over there, Camp B, B block. Throw some lighter fluid on me, burned me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was he in the cell with you?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, he wasn't in the cell. At the time, I had been out the shower, and they was letting them out of the shower, out the cell, and some dude, he had lighter fluid, and a book, lit it up and dashed it in my cell, all on me. It hit me, and bounced over, and I had 3rd degree burns.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh my God.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Over half of my body. Lucky to be living here. Now I went to New Orleans, and stayed in the Charity for a few years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: For a few years in the Charity Hospital?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: In New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Did he ever get punished?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Well, I don't really know what happened.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was he here when you came back from the hospital?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, he wasn't here. He wasn't here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You never saw him again?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I ain't never seen him again.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow. Did that happen a lot, people setting people on fire?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, not a lot, but that happened to me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: A lot.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. What's the worst thing you've seen here?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Worst thing I've seen is the bucks and things they had in here. They had a lot of them didn't want to go to work, they'd buck and create trouble.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: With the free folks. And where it take place then. You got to go in there and tell them, buck them.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Until they get straight.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: That's the worst thing I've seen in my life. A lot of them got beat up, messed up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Do you remember learning about the Civil Rights Movement, and Black Panthers, and Martin Luther King? Did you have access to information about was going on outside of prison in the 1960s?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Not really, they had the Black Panthers here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: What I mean. One supposedly killed a free man. He got out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, Woodfox?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Woodfox. All these people, yeah, Woodfox.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: He's in New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, they didn't want to let him get out. He got out too, you see what I mean?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, he did so many years, and I think he did more years in solitary confinement than any American in history, Woodfox.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: What, in the cell? No, I don't believe it. I don't believe that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: There's some people that have done more time than him?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: What do you think about me, I'm telling you about me, living in a cell?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, I mean in solitary confinement.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, I bet I stayed in there longer than him, probably longer than him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, that's true.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: If I come in here longer than 53, and 60 something years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yes. Yeah, that's true.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: He got out a few years ago.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: He did.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's true. Have you spent very much time in solitary confinement?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Who me? Locked up?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In a cell by yourself, you can't come out.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah I been, I spent a lot of time in the cell, a lot of times, I ain't want to come out. They want to let me out, and I stay right there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Why did you want to stay in there?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I just didn't want to be around a lot of the convicts.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. It's safer in there.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Safe.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is it safer to be in the cell than in general population?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, well, to me it's about the same.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: About the same.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What do you want people to know about Angola?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: What do I want them to know? What they don't know of, everything happen here. If people get in the streets, they know about it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Just like right now. If someone go home and happen, it'll be out there before the sun go down. That's right. That's right. And some of them don't want to hear it, some of them, so.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think it's fair to sentence somebody to life without parole?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Sorry?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think it's fair to give somebody the punishment of life without parole?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Do I really think?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No sir. I don't. I don't believe in it. See, a dude like me, all the time I been in penitentiary, what I'm saying? Just like a lot of these dudes get let out. A lot of these dudes be here like me, ain't going to get out, giving me preparation to get out, make it hard on me. And next person that get a life. And they had some that had life and got out. Had more luck than us.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Some get lucky.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, get lucky. Lucky enough to get out. Since I've been here, and I've seen a lot of them had life. I've seen some of them had 10-6 that got out. I've seen one with 2 10-6, and got out. After he got out that's when Mr. Edwards stopped the 10-6.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If somebody comes to you and says, Mr. Robinson, we will grant you geriatric parole, what do you see yourself doing, if you get out of here, what will you do?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Go out there, and try to make a living somewhere.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think you've worked hard enough already? Maybe it's time for somebody else to take care of you.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: See when I come here like, they were working you. See they ain't doing nothing now. Go out there and pick a little greens, pick a little cotton or something like that, but when I come here they were working them. They ain't doing nothing now, but walking.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Know what I'm saying? But look, I, I still can do a little work, I mean, enough get to by.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, sure.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right. I'm 81 years old. And I'm still in good shape. More better than a lot of old peoples in here. They got them in wheelchairs. Some faking it and some ain't. See I can't go through life faking.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right. If I'm sick, I'm sick. If I'm good I'm good.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. What jobs have you done at Angola?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Well most of the jobs I've had since I've been in here was orderlies. Orderlies cleaning up in the building and the dormitories. In the prison down here I was a general orderly.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: An orderly?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, just cleaning up, like.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, sure. Is that pretty much it? Did you ever have a job like a trade or a skill?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, not really. See, when I come here, they wasn't going to school or anything like they doing now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: And people were hard on you. They didn't care whether you get a trade or not. But it done changed now, it's different.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Mr. Robinson, if you came to prison today as a young man, if you came to prison today as an 18 year old boy, what would you do, because it's very different now than it was when you came?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, I would try to go to school, or learn something to get a trade, yeah it's a lot different now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. You would learn a trade? When you see these young guys coming in Mr. Robinson, these young guys, 18, 19 year olds, and you look at them, and you think back to when you were here, when you came in, do you, what kind of advice would you give the guys who were coming in? The guys who were coming in now, 18 years old.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, well…

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And they came up to you and said, Mr. Robinson, tell me, give me some advice.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, you see a lot right now, you can give advice to them, they'll take it, and they got some will make it. Some of them got it in their head, they don't want to be around that coming up, what I'm saying? Don't want to listen to nothing. Got a lot of them like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: But I'd try to give them advice, by being around them every day, they got a bunch of them around me. In the dorm with me and things.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, what would you tell them? If you had to give them advice what would you tell them?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Ain't nothing wrong with you dude, but try to do it right, but I came in through the same shoes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. What's your typical day like, nowadays? What's your typical day? What's your daily routine like, now?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Well, now, getting out of here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Now what do you do every day?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: What I do?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, what's your day like, when you wake up in the morning, what do you do until you go to bed at night?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I do a little work. I walk the yard, and I'm still a dormitory orderly in my dorm.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I'm a helper.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: A helper.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Which camp are you in?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Camp D.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Camp D.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I'm a trusty. Class A trusty.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's right. Mr. Robinson, do you have anybody who visits you here?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: No, I lost all of them when my mama and them died, and my dad.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did your mom used to come visit you here?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right. I had a few people seeing me in the Angolite like Rideau was writing. Some of them went to writing me. They called them pen pals. I had about 2 or 3 of them. They've seen that I ain't been in penitentiary so he's been in penitentiary. But I had a couple on my list, that come seen me a few times. Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You don't have any children, right? No? You were too young.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I never had any children. I got busted.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You were busted too young.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah. 16 years old, 15 years old, I ain't never had that kind of thing. I been right here. And in a home. Where those homes at in Scotland? Where they had the women's in the, I believe they call it the LCI.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: LCIW?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, you see, when I was going there, you ain't had nothing but men. What I'm saying? Then they built it up, they have women's too.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: It's called, it's called LCIW, at St. Gabriel. It's about 900 women there. If you come before the pardon board, what would you tell them?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Well I would tell them, "man I want to get out." I've been on the pardon board a few times, but they had the wrong people on there, so I ain't get no help. What this man name was out of New Orleans, he was on the pardon board, when Governor Edwards was going out, he come up here on the pardon board. What you call his name. He's from New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, I don't know.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Them dudes, a lot of dudes from New Orleans he got them in the penitentiary. A lot of times he come sat on that pardon board. He was sitting on there when I went on the pardon board.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What would they tell you?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: They turned me down.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If you could go before the pardon board tomorrow, what would you tell them?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: That I'd like to get out. That I getting out of here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: A person, in penitentiary, 60 something years and it ain't changed yet, and it ain't going to never change. That's too long to be dead.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Are you a changed man?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When do you think you changed? How old were you when you think you turned around?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Well, I would say about 40 or 50 years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Like in your 40s or 50s?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah. I went to seeing things as I go along. I said, "Well it's time to try to change, right".

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. How old were you when somebody set fire to you? How old were you then? Were you a young man?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I believe I was young. This happened in 1965.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok. Yeah so you were a young man.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I was still young.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. 1965…

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: They had me over in that block there. B block, right over there. Never forget that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. It's amazing you survived.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Right, 3rd degree burn, a dude get 3rd degree burn he lucky to live. Over a third of my body. One point, he throw it on me, bounced over me, and he hit me too in the face, over my shoulder, down my back, the fluid, gas.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Mr. Robinson, what's the worst part for you about being in prison now?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Worst part? I don't know, I know one thing, I need to be out. Worst thing is being in prison this long.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. What would you do if you get out?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: I'd go somewhere and make me a living, and start all over again.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Start all over again?

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah. They say the longer you live the more you learn, well I learned a lot of things, what I'm saying, so.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright. Well, Mr. Robinson I really enjoyed talking to you, thank you very much.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah, I enjoyed talking to you too.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I appreciate you taking the time.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You definitely have seen more than anybody else that I've talked to.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Yeah right, I've caught plenty of hell in this penitentiary. I hope I'll be lucky enough to get out. All I got to do is try to live, I might make it, the good Lord might.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: This paperwork you gave me, what do I have to do with this here?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You don't have to do anything with it.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: Oh just, keep it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You can keep it if you want it. Yeah, it's for you. I'm going to give you a card with my contact information on it too in case you have any questions.

transcript.speaker: Sammie
transcript.content: All right.
